div.head: Pollux traduzione
div.p: (5) God and gods and daemons; for thus Homer seems to call the gods daemones. And Plato too called ‘the helmsman of the universe’ the ‘greatest daemon’, since the ‘divine’ and the ‘daemonic’ have the same use.

(6) And the place where we worship the gods is ‘holy place’ and ‘temple’; where we establish them is ‘sacred enclosure’ and a ‘precint’; for the more precise call ‘sacred enclosure (τέμενος)’ the one [dedicated] to the heroes, but the poets also call so that to the gods, as the tragedians ‘to the sacred enclosure of god.’ And the [structure] before [a temple] is ‘prodomos’,

(7) and the one behind it is ‘opisthodomos’, and the entrance is ‘propylaia’. What we worship are ‘statues (ἀγάλματα)’, ‘xoana’, ‘statues (ἕδη) of gods’, ‘images of gods’, ‘raffigurations’, ‘representations’, ‘figures (τυπώματα, εἴδη, ἰδέαι)’. I would not approve ‘bretas (‘wooden image’)’ or ‘deikelon’ ⌠because they are poetic⌡. Upon which we sacrifice or light a fire is an ‘altar’, ‘censer’, ‘hestia’: some have named it so. Nonetheless, it would be most properly called so [hestia]

(8) the one in the prytaneion, upon which the unquenchable fire is kindled. ἐσχάρα (‘fire-place’) specifically seems to be so called the place upon which we offer sacrifices to heroes, some among the poets have also called so the altar of the gods, tough. The area within the lustral water (‘περιρραντήρια’) could be ‘sacred’, ‘holy’, ‘consecrated’, ‘hallowed’, ‘inviolable’ – although I have not yet encountered this word –

(9) the area outside is ‘profane’, for ‘unholy’ would be more appropriate for impure places. If any part of the sanctuary is not to be trodden, you could call this ‘adyton’, ‘untouchable’ and ‘untouched’

(10) ‘secret’, and ‘anaktoron (‘shrine’)’. And places let free to the gods are ‘groves (ἄλση)’, and ‘sacred precincts (τεμένη)’ and ‘enclosures (ἕρκη)’, and the circle around them is ‘peribolos’. And if some place is inviolable, say this ‘place of refuge (κρησφύγετον)’ and ‘of escape (φύξιμον)’, and ‘holy boundaries’, within which there is safety for the suppliants. And the land let free for the gods is ‘holy soil’ and ὀργάς (‘sacred land’).
